Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Viruses of the Protozoan Parasites Perkinsus spp.: Isolation and Characterization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Oysters and clams are often challenged by parasites, including Perkinsus species. Perkinsus spp., causative of Dermo disease, can lead to mass mortalities of farmed and wild bivalve populations and hence have important detrimental ecological and economic consequences. Perkinsus is on the World Organization for Animal Health's list of reportable diseases. Most of the studies aimed to understand and intervene against Dermo have centered in a game of two: parasite and host. However, previous ultrastructural studies have shown the presence of virus-like particles in the nucleus of the parasite. Yet, nothing is known about these viruses' genetics, mechanism of infection, or consequences on Perkinsus ecology. Research on other parasitic protozoa (including some with human hosts) has revealed many interesting biological phenomena that suggest that there is every reason to expect that viruses have a profound effect on the propagation, life style and virulence of Perkinsus spp. Proving viral infection of Perkinsus spp. and understanding the host's functional responses to infections will represent a paradigm shift in our thinking about Perkinsus spp. ecology and virulence toward their bivalve hosts. Furthermore, it will open the door to new approaches for intervention against the disease-causing agent. This project is considered high risk-high payoff since, thus far, compelling evidence of viruses infectious to Perkinsus is based on ultrastructural studies using electron microscopy, but information to assess ease of virus isolation is lacking.

This project focuses on isolating and characterizing viruses that infect Perkinsus spp. This is a necessary first step toward understanding the dynamics of viral infection of Perkinsus spp. cells and the effects of viruses on the propagation and virulence of this protozoan parasite. In this study, work will focus on the three Perkinsus spp. (P. marinus, P. chesapeaki, and P. olseni) for which there is previous evidence of viral infection. The investigators will isolate viruses specific to several Perkinsus strains already in culture as well as from new Perkinsus spp. isolates. Effort will be put in establishing cultures from those isolates and to optimize propagation and maintenance of the viruses in the laboratory. They will also conduct growth curve experiments, and investigate the effect of viral infection on Perkinsus physiology and as a potential trigger for cell differentiation. Having well characterized model virus-host systems in culture is essential to investigate the environmental parameters that affect viral replication success and specificity. It will also aid in understanding the mechanisms of virus-host interactions and their ecological and physiological consequences through hypothesis driven experimental manipulation. Overall, this project will help to evaluate the ubiquity of viruses that infect Perkinsus spp. and the roles they play in shaping the life cycle and the virulence of these parasites of bivalves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oysters and clams are often challenged by protozoan parasites. Perkinsus spp. cause Dermo disease leading to mortalities of farmed and wild bivalve populations and hence have important detrimental economic and ecological consequences. However, in some areas, high Dermo prevalence does not result in noticeable mortality levels. Better understanding of the factors that contribute to the virulence level of Perkinsus spp. or "races" is needed to aid in developing new approaches for prevention, control, and management of Dermo disease. Previous studies had shown the presence of virus-like particles inside Perkinsus spp. cells. Yet, nothing is known about the true nature of those virus-resembling particles or their possible impact on Perkinsus' biology and ecology. Research on other protozoan parasites (including some that infect humans) has revealed that viruses have a profound have a profound effect on the parasite's propagation, life cycle, and virulence. 

            The aim of this project was aimed to isolate and characterize virus-like particles in Perkinsus spp., using state of the art microbiology and molecular biology tools, as a first step toward understanding the dynamics and consequences of a possible viral infection. This project was deemed high risk-high payoff since compelling evidence of viruses infectious to Perkinsus was based on ultrastructural studies using transmission electron microscopy, but information to assess ease of virus isolation was lacking. Perkinsus spp. can be grown in the laboratory as pure cultures without the need for the bivalve host. In this study, work focused on the three Perkinsus spp. (P. marinus, P. chesapeaki, and P. olseni) for which there was previous evidence of virus-like particles. Electron microscopy analysis showed that cultures of P. marinus TXsc ATCC 50983 and P. olseni ALG-1 ATCC 50984 still contained 40-50 nm virus-like particles as revealed by past studies. Interestingly, some of those cultures have been maintained in the laboratory for over 20 years. This result indicates an intrinsic and persistent relationship between the putative viruses and the parasite cells. However, flow cytometry analysis, a method for counting cells and DNA viruses, did not detect the presence of virus-like particles in the cultures outside the Perkinsus spp. cells, what suggests that the virus-like particles are not released from the cells or that they could be RNA viruses that are missed by flow cytometry. Furthermore, the virus-like particles could not be physically separated from the parasite’s organelles and vesicles. The investigators also sequenced purified RNA (transcriptomics) from the Perkinsus spp. cultures to search for genes of viral origin. For the age of cultures used to extract RNA and for the sequencing depth possible within the scope and resources for this project, the transcriptomics approach did not support the presence of Perkinsus-viruses. Positive outcomes from this project include:

-        Development of an agar-based method for growing Perkinsus spp. cells. The results were published at a peer-reviewed scientific journal: Cold ER, Freyria NJ, Martínez Martínez J, Fernández Robledo JA (2016). An Agar-Based Method for Plating Marine Protozoan Parasites of the Genus Perkinsus.  PLoS One. DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0155015). This method has multiple potential applications for investigating diverse aspects of Perkinsus spp. biology, developing new molecular tools, and for biotechnological applications.

-        Training next generation scientists:

  • Undergraduate student (Emma R. Cold, lead author in the publication cited above).
  • Visiting Master’s student (Mathieu Lazare) received training in cell culture, virus isolation, and molecular techniques.
  • This award provided side projects for two postdocs in the teams of the PIs. For one of the postdocs (Ananda Bhattacharjee), this side project opportunity has been an introduction to Perkinsus spp. and to parasite ecology in general and has offered him an opportunity to further develop skills in bioinformatics analysis of transcriptomes. The second postdoc (Raghavendra Yadavalli) is being trained in virus ecology aspects and virus isolation techniques. This work is complementary to his independent project goals. He brings knowledge of parasite cell biology methods and confocal microscopy. He is currently designing further experiments to investigate the nature of previously observed (TEM) virus-like particles. This work is continuing outside the timeframe of this award.

-        The transcriptomics analysis has yielded a catalog of highly expressed Perkinsus spp. genes that are being used to build new Perkinsus transfection vectors for homologous and heterologous expression of genes in Perkinsus spp. for investigation of Perkinsus spp. biology and for biotechnology applications, e.g., candidates for vaccines of veterinary and human health relevance (ongoing NSF-CBET award #1701480 to co-I José A. Fernández Robledo). This data is becoming publicly available and can be mined by other researchers as needed to facilitate and enhanced their research.

-        Communication of results to both science audiences and to shellfish farmers in the Maine Shellfish Working Group (~100 attendees) at their annual meeting, which was hosted by Bigelow Laboratory.
